awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Enabling On-site Nitrate Fertilizer Production: An Absorption Unit to Efficiently and Selectively Capture Nitrates
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will transform the production, distribution, and application of nitrogen fertilizer, with a new process that is far more sustainable and will save farmers money. This project enables on-farm production of nitrogen fertilizers by progressing the scientific understanding, and subsequent increase in the operational efficiency, of a cutting-edge fertilizer production system. Increased system efficiency will decrease the cost of these systems, which provide instant access to pH-controlled fertilizer for farms. Due to the type and availability of nitrogen provided, there is an opportunity to greatly reduce emissions, reduce nitrogen runoff, and generally transform farming toward a more sustainable future. If successful, this project can also positively impact nitric acid production systems for other uses and add to US leadership in the fight against global hunger by increasing crop yields in developing countries where fertilizer is scarce but vital to their populations.

This proposal encompasses the research and development of an absorption unit to improve the systemic efficiency of plasma-derived nitrate production. This Phase I project will overcome key technical hurdles with respect to an innovative nitrogen fertilizer production system, designed for on-farm use. Particularly, the product absorption structure requires dedicated R&D to improve both gas product absorption efficiency and product selectivity. Specifically, a research test platform will be built for rapidly testing methods to oxidize a transitional product and capture the final product, nitrate fertilizer compounds. The goal of these strategies is to improve the overall efficiency of the system by 40% and enable cost competitive, distributed nitrogen fertilization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Nitricity is developing a technology with the support of an NSF SBIR grant that produces fertilizer using only air, water, and renewable electricity.

For the past century, fertilizer has been made in billion-dollar Haber-Bosch (HB) facilities located hundreds to thousands of miles away from farmers who use nitrogen. Market inefficiencies, chemical transformations and safety hazards are incurred in the distribution of fertilizer to farmers, leading to a 2-5x difference between production cost and end-user costs. The incumbent production, distribution, and application of the fertilizers results in 6-7% of global GHG emissions. In contrast, Nitricity's new approach produces a high-quality, low-emissions factor, and locally-made fertilizer using renewable energy rather than coal or natural gas.

The chemical process Nitricity uses has previously been referred to as the "burning of air". Specifically, we use a plasma reactor and absorption system to cost effectively convert N2/O2 and water into nitric acid (HNO3). This nitric acid is a precursor to many types of nitrogen fertilizer today, including calcium nitrate, nitro-phosphates, and aqueous potassium nitrate. The first step in Nitricity's process is to send air through a plasma reactor to make NO and NO2. The second step includes absorption of these species into water and the reaction to HNO3. It is this second step that Nitricity's NSF SBIR Phase I award was focused on.

The system cost and overall efficiency of the system is directly affected by chemical absorption. Nitricity's R&D efforts in our NSF SBIR Phase I grant were to improve absorption efficiencies. In order to develop a successful absorption structure for our system, we focused on two key approaches. These included the oxidation of NO to NO2 before any absorption and the alteration of specific parameters of the absorption columns to improve their performance.). Oxidation of NO to NO2 is beneficial because it leads to more efficient absorption. NO gas is slowly absorbed in water in the form of nitrites, whereas NO2 is absorbed more quickly in form of nitrates. Nitrates are highly favorable as some crops have sensitivities to nitrites which can negatively affect their growth and development. In our process during NSF SBIR Phase I, our goal was to test various oxidative enhancements, using the materials and new reactor designs that can be readily applicable to our distributed fertilizer production system. By optimizing around key system variables like unit sizing, flow rates, and compositions, we were able to hit our key performance metrics that we believe will translate to a viable commercial product.

In conclusion, we successfully executed the first phase of this NSF SBIR grant project, where we achieved our milestones, surpassing a NOx absorption efficiency threshold. These results will be critical to the overall system efficiency as well as our ability to hit environmental emissions regulations. Once scaled up, our process will offer farmers and farming communities a way to make the fertilizer the require- A low-cost fertilizer optimized for crop growth and sustainability rather than for fossil fuels and shipping pipelines.
